Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Silencing of SLC7A11 sensitized HT-1080 cells to erastin-induced death, whereas transfection of HT-1080 cells with a plasmid encoding SLC7A11 conferred protection from erastin- and sulfasalazine-induced death.
Test method: RT-qPCR, siRNA, gene transfection, cell viability

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: RNAi-mediated GPX4 knockdown induces ferroptosis.
Test method: Affinity-based chemoproteomics, western blotting, and RNAi
Test setting: HRAS mutant BJeLR-engineered tumor cells, HT-1080 cells, xenograft mouse model (athymic nude mice injected with four million HT-1080 cells)
Pathway: GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Aldo-keto reductase family 1 member C1
Evidence: Up-regulated in DU-145 erastin-resistant clones. Participate in the detoxification of toxic lipid metabolites. May confer partial resistance to erastin by enhancing the detoxification of reactive aldehydes generated downstream of the oxidative destruction of the plasma membrane during ferroptosis.
Test method: RNA-seq, glutamate release assay, cell growth, flow cytometry

Name: Aldo-keto reductase family 1 member C2
Evidence: Up-regulated in DU-145 erastin-resistant clones. Participate in the detoxification of toxic lipid metabolites. May confer partial resistance to erastin by enhancing the detoxification of reactive aldehydes generated downstream of the oxidative destruction of the plasma membrane during ferroptosis.
Test method: RNA-seq, glutamate release assay, cell growth, flow cytometry

Name: Aldo-keto reductase family 1 member C3
Evidence: Up-regulated in DU-145 erastin-resistant clones. Participate in the detoxification of toxic lipid metabolites. May confer partial resistance to erastin by enhancing the detoxification of reactive aldehydes generated downstream of the oxidative destruction of the plasma membrane during ferroptosis.
Test method: RNA-seq, glutamate release assay, cell growth, flow cytometry

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Knockout of glutathione peroxidase 4 (Gpx4) causes cell death in a pathologically relevant form of ferroptosis. Knockdown renders cells more sensitive to ferroptosis-inducing agents.
Test method: Cell viability assessment, siRNA
Test setting: Mouse embryonic fibroblast (MEF) cells (Pfa1 cells), Gpx4−/− cells and mice, HK-2 cells
Pathway: GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: RB transcriptional corepressor 1
Evidence: Rb knock-down cells exposed to sorafenib encounter ferroptosis. Lack of Rb sensitized HCC cells to the induction of ferroptosis.
Test method: RNA interference, cell viability assay, oxidative stress measurement
Test setting: HCC cell lines Huh7 and PLC/PRF5; Balb/c nude mice received tumour xenografts derived from HCC cells.

Name: Heat shock protein family B (small) member 1
Evidence: Knockdown of HSF1 and HSPB1 enhances erastin-induced ferroptosis, whereas heat shock pretreatment and overexpression of HSPB1 inhibits erastin-induced ferroptosis.
Test method: RNAi, RT-qPCR, western blot, cell viability
Test setting: HeLa and U2OS cells, human xenograft mouse tumor derived from HeLa (#CCL-2) cells.

Name: Heat shock transcription factor 1
Evidence: Knockdown of HSF1 and HSPB1 enhances erastin-induced ferroptosis, whereas heat shock pretreatment and overexpression of HSPB1 inhibits erastin-induced ferroptosis.
Test method: RNAi, RT-qPCR, western blot, cell viability
Test setting: HeLa and U2OS cells, human xenograft mouse tumor derived from HeLa (#CCL-2) cells.

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Overexpressed in human cancer specimens. Overexpression inhibits ROS-induced ferroptosis.
Test method: Western blot, cell death test, ChIP assay, RT-PCR, immunofluorescence staining, colony formation assay, TUNEL and BrdU assay
Test setting: H1299 cells, mouse embryonic fibroblasts, transgenic mice; colon, liver and kidney tumour samples; mouse xenograft

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Ex vivo, Gpx4-deficient T cells rapidly accumulated membrane lipid peroxides and concomitantly underwent cell death driven by ferroptosis.
Test method: Viability assays, flow cytometry, lipid peroxidation assay

Name: Glutamate-cysteine ligase catalytic subunit
Evidence: RNAi knockdown sensitized cell death induced by cystine starvation.
Test method: RNAi, qPCR

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Overexpression of SLC7A11 considerably abrogated ferroptosis.
Test method: Cell death quantification, gene transfection, western blot

Name: Nuclear factor, erythroid 2 like 2
Evidence: NRF2 plays a central role in protecting hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells against ferroptosis
Test method: Cell Viability Analysis, western blot, RNAi, qRT-PCR
Test setting: HepG2, Hepa1‐6, Hep3B, and SNU‐182 cells, C57BL/6 mice

Name: Sequestosome 1
Evidence: The interaction between p62 and Keap1 increased following erastin and sorafenib treatment. Knockdown of p62 suppressed NRF2 expression and promoted growth inhibition with increased ferroptotic events including GSH depletion, lipid ROS production, and an increase of iron levels.
Test method: Immunoprecipitation assay, shRNA knockdown, iron assay, lipid peroxidation assay, glutathione assay, cell viability
Test setting: HepG2, Hepa1‐6, Hep3B, and SNU‐182 cells
Pathway: SQSTM1 :-: KEAP1, KEAP1 :-: NFE2L2, NFE2L2 :-: Ferroptosis

Name: NAD(P)H quinone dehydrogenase 1
Evidence: Knockdown of p62, quinone oxidoreductase‐1, heme oxygenase‐1, and ferritin heavy chain‐1 by RNA interference in HCC cells promoted ferroptosis in response to erastin and sorafenib.
Test method: qRT‐PCR, RNA interference
Test setting: HepG2, Hepa1‐6, Hep3B, and SNU‐182 cells

Name: Heme oxygenase 1
Evidence: Knockdown of p62, quinone oxidoreductase‐1, heme oxygenase‐1, and ferritin heavy chain‐1 by RNA interference in HCC cells promoted ferroptosis in response to erastin and sorafenib.
Test method: qRT‐PCR, RNA interference
Test setting: HepG2, Hepa1‐6, Hep3B, and SNU‐182 cells

Name: Ferritin heavy chain 1
Evidence: Knockdown of p62, quinone oxidoreductase‐1, heme oxygenase‐1, and ferritin heavy chain‐1 by RNA interference in HCC cells promoted ferroptosis in response to erastin and sorafenib.
Test method: qRT‐PCR, RNA interference
Test setting: HepG2, Hepa1‐6, Hep3B, and SNU‐182 cells

Name: Mucin 1, cell surface associated
Evidence: MUC1-C (C-terminal subunit) blocks erastin-induced ferroptosis and induces increases in GSH.
Test method: shRNA, GSH level measurement, cell death test
Pathway: MUC1 :+: System Xc-, System Xc- :+: GSH, GSH :-: Ferroptosis

Name: Solute carrier family 3 member 2
Evidence: Required for in vitro cell survival because of its role in protecting cells from ferroptosis.
Test method: Cell survival test
Pathway: SLC3A2 :+: System Xc-, System Xc- :-: Ferroptosis

Name: Metallothionein 1G
Evidence: A negative regulator of ferroptosis in HCC cells. Knockdown of MT‐1G by RNA interference increases glutathione depletion and lipid peroxidation, which contributes to sorafenib‐induced ferroptosis.
Test method: RNA interference, cell viability assay, colony formation assay, western blot, qRT-PCR, glutathione assay, lipid peroxidation assay
Test setting: HCC cells (HepaG2, Hep3B, and Huh7 cells), nude mice.

Name: Nuclear factor, erythroid 2 like 2
Evidence: Required for sorafenib‐induced expression of MT‐1G which is a ferroptosis suppressor.
Test method: shRNA, qRT-PCR, western blot
Caution: Its ability to induce MT1G was validated, but its role in ferroptosis needs validation.

Name: Solute carrier family 40 member 1
Evidence: Involved in siramesine and lapatinib-induced ferroptotic cell death. Its expression is decreased after treatment with siramesine alone or in combination with lapatinib. Overexpression FPN resulted in decreased ROS and cell death whereas knockdown of FPN increased cell death after siramesine and lapatinib treatment.
Test method: Western blot, densitometry quantification, siRNA, gene transfection, cell death test
Pathway: SLC40A1 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Knockdown increased cell death.
Test method: siRNA, western blot, cell death test

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Knockdown increased cell death.
Test method: siRNA, western blot, cell death test

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Inhibition induces ferroptosis. Silencing of the SLC7A11 gene increases the cisplatin sensitivity of resistant HNC cells.
Test method: Cell viability, western blot, siRNA or shRNA, glutathione and ROS production measurements
Test setting: AMC-HN3R, -HN4R, and -HN9R head and neck cancer cells, BALB/c male nude mice

Name: CDGSH iron sulfur domain 1
Evidence: Genetic inhibition of CISD1 contributes to erastin-induced ferroptosis. Stabilization of the iron sulfur cluster of CISD1 inhibits ferroptosis.
Test method: Cytotoxicity assays, western blot, q-PCR, RNAi
Pathway: CISD1 :-: Mitochondrial lipid ROS, Mitochondrial lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Elevated levels of expression are resistant to erastin-induced ferroptosis. Repression of SLC7A11 expression by p53 sensitized cells to undergo erastin-induced ferroptosis.
Test method: Western blot, cell death assay, qPCR

Name: FA complementation group D2
Evidence: Inhibits erastin-induced ferroptosis. Plays a novel role in the negative regulation of ferroptosis.
Test method: Cell viability assay, Q-PCR, western blot, iron assay, lipid peroxidation assay, glutathione assay

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Protects lipid peroxidation. Cell damage induced by GPx4 ablation is involved in ferroptosis.

Name: Nuclear factor, erythroid 2 like 2
Evidence: Nrf2 activation contributes to the resistance of HNCs to artesunate-induced ferroptosis. Nrf2 inhibition sensitizes head and neck cancer cells to artesunate-induced ferroptosis.

Test setting: Head and neck cancer cells (HN2–10), nude mice

Name: Ferritin mitochondrial
Evidence: Overexpression significantly inhibited erastin-induced ferroptosis.

Pathway: FTMT :-: Labile iron pool, Labile iron pool :+: Ferroptosis

Pathway: HSPA5 :+: GPX4, GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Evidence: Inhibition of ATF4 expression increased erastin-induced cell death. ATF4 results in the induction of HSPA5, which in turn protects against GPX4 protein degradation and subsequent ferroptosis.

Pathway: ATF4 :+: HSPA5, HSPA5 :+: GPX4, GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Solute carrier family 7 member 11
Evidence: Slc7a11 deletion increases susceptibility to iron overload-induced ferroptosis.

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Ferroptosis drives neurodegeneration in Gpx4BIKO mice.

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Downregulation conferred increased sensitivity to ferroptosis following cystine deprivation.

Pathway: GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Heme oxygenase 1
Evidence: Demonsrates antiferroptotic role. HO-1 deficiency promotes erastin-induced ferroptosis.

Pathway: ATF4 :+: xCT, xCT :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Evidence: Inhibits ferroptosis in human colorectal cancer (CRC) cells. Loss of TP53 restored erastin sensitivity. Inhibits cell death induction by erastin in human CRC cells.

Evidence: Delta Np63 alpha can inhibit ferroptosis independent of p53. Overexpression protects cells from ferroptosis-inducing agents.

Evidence: Overexperession of SLC7A11 attenuated BAY-inhibited cell viability by ferroptosis.

Name: Perilipin 2
Evidence: An indispensable gene and protein in the suppression of ferroptosis caused by abnormal lipometabolism in gastric carcinoma.
Test method: Cell proliferation and clonogenic assay, cell survival analysis, xenografts tumor, RNA-seq, RT‑qPCR, ROS assay
Test setting: SGC7901 and MGC803 cells, nude mice

Name: microRNA 212
Evidence: Overexpression of miR-212-5p attenuated ferroptosis while downregulation of miR-212-5p promoted ferroptotic cell death.
Test method: Controlled cortical impact model, iron assay, MDA assay, RT-PCR, western blotting, cell death
Test setting: HT22 and Neuro-2a cells, C57BL/6 J mice

Name: Ferritin 1 Heavy Chain Homolog
Evidence: Reduced heavy chain levels caused severe mitochondrial defects and ferroptosis.
Test method: RT-qPCR, immunohistochemistry, EdU staining, TUNEL staining

Name: Apoptosis inducing factor mitochondria associated 2
Evidence: A glutathione-independent ferroptosis suppressor. Pharmacological targeting of FSP1 strongly synergizes with GPX4 inhibitors to trigger ferroptosis.
Test method: Expression cloning, cell death, cell viability, LDH assay, western blot, LC-MS, NADH consumption assay
Pathway: FPS1 :+: CoQ10, CoQ10 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Apoptosis inducing factor mitochondria associated 2
Evidence: A potent ferroptosis-resistance factor. Positively correlates with ferroptosis resistance.
Test method: Synthetic lethal CRISPR-Cas9 screen, cell death, western blotting, lipid droplet fractionation, glutathione measurement, tumour xenograft growth, CoQ measurement

Pathway: FPS1 :+: CoQ10, CoQ10 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Lysosomal associated membrane protein 2
Evidence: Knockdown promoted ferroptosis.
Test method: Cell viability, western blot, ROS induction, glutathione assay, lipid peroxidation assay
Pathway: LAMP2 :+: Cysteine, Cysteine :+: GSH, GSH :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: ZFP36 ring finger protein
Evidence: ZFP36 plasmid impaired FBXW7 plasmid-induced HSC ferroptosis. Overexpression of Zfp36 impaired erastin- or sorafenib-induced ferroptosis.
Test method: Cell viability, lipid peroxidation, iron, GSH and ROS assays, western blot, RT-PCR, RNA-seq

Name: Glutathione peroxidase 4
Evidence: Depletion or inhibition resulted in cell death by ferroptosis.
Test method: Quantitative proteomic analysis, siRNA, RNA-seq and qRT-PCR, cell viability, lipid peroxidation assay, GSH measurement, western blot
Test setting: H9c2 and C2C12 cells, rat ventricular myocytes, C57BL/6 mice
Pathway: GPX4 :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Name: Prominin 2
Evidence: Induced by ferroptotic stress and promotes resistance to ferroptotic cell death. Facilitates ferroptosis resistance in mammary epithelial and breast carcinoma cells.
Test method: RNA-seq, western blot, qPCR, siRNA, cell count, cell death, iron assay
Pathway: Prominin2 :+: Ferritin-containing MVB, Ferritin-containing MVB :-: Ferroptosis

Name: Charged multivesicular body protein 5
Evidence: Ferroptosis activators increase ESCRT-III subunits (e.g., CHMP5 and CHMP6). Knockdown of CHMP5 or CHMP6 sensitizes human cancer cells to ferroptosis.
Test method: RNAi, western blot, iron, malondialdehyde and cytotoxicity assays

Name: Charged multivesicular body protein 6
Evidence: Ferroptosis activators increase ESCRT-III subunits (e.g., CHMP5 and CHMP6). Knockdown of CHMP5 or CHMP6 sensitizes human cancer cells to ferroptosis.
Test method: RNAi, western blot, iron, malondialdehyde and cytotoxicity assays
Test setting: PANC1 and HepG2 cells, athymic nude or B6 mice

Evidence: Inhibition completely resensitizes resistant melanoma cells to ferroptosis execution.

Evidence: Knockdown in erastin-resistant cells caused ferroptotic cell death, while overexpression conferred ferroptosis resistance.

Pathway: CBS :+: Cystathionine, Cystathionine :+: Cysteine, Cysteine :+: GSH, GSH :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Evidence: Genetically repression of NRF2 enhanced ferroptosis susceptibility.

Pathway: NFE2L2 :+: CBS :+: Cystathionine, Cystathionine :+: Cysteine, Cysteine :+: GSH, GSH :-: Lipid ROS, Lipid ROS :+: Ferroptosis

Pathway: CAV-1 :+: xCT, xCT :+: GPX4, GPX4 :-: Ferroptosis, CAV-1 :-: RNS, RNS :+: Ferroptosis

Evidence: Gch1 overexpression and its downstream metabolites BH4/BH2 rescue from ferroptosis. Inhibition of GCH1 activity can sensitize resistant cancer cells to ferroptosis induction.
